did.abstract: Internationally recognized librarian; director of the University of Michigan Library. Correspondence and subject files relating to professional activities.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The bulk of the collection was transferred from the Graduate Library of the University of Michigan in 1975. Donor number 1278. Smaller additions were received from the Bishop family.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

altformavail.p: Bishop's student notebooks from philosophy courses taught by John Dewey (Box 24) are also available on microfilm.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., William Warner Bishop Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: William Warner Bishop was librarian of the University of Michigan from 1915 until his retirement in 1941. After graduating from the University of Michigan (M.A. 1893), Bishop taught Greek at Missouri Wesleyan College (1893-1894) and then became an instructor in New Testament Greek and assistant librarian at Garrett Biblical Institute in Evanston, Illinois. He was a fellow at the American School for Classical Studies in Rome in 1898-1899. On his return to the United States he became librarian and instructor in Latin at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, New York, where he served from 1899 to 1902. Two years as head cataloger at Princeton University preceded his appointment as reference librarian at the Library of Congress in 1904. Bishop remained at the Library of Congress serving from 1907 to 1915 as superintendent of the reading room. In 1915, he was appointed librarian at the University of Michigan, succeeding Theodore Wesley Koch.

As librarian, Bishop was greatly responsible for the growth of the collection, the development and training of the staff, and the contacts established with European bookdealers and librarians. One of Bishop's most significant contributions was the establishment under his leadership of a department of library science to train individuals in bibliographical and other library-related skills.

Bishop was highly respected within his profession. He served as consultant on many of the library projects sponsored by the Carnegie Corporation; and he was chairman of the Advisory Group on College Libraries which assisted in building up the book collections of many college libraries in the United States and Canada. In no area of library work did he make a greater contribution than in international relations. In 1928 Bishop was invited by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace to head the American group of librarians and others in initiating the reorganization of the Vatican Library. In addition, he served as president of the International Federation of Library Associations from 1931 to 1936; and as chairman of the International Relations Committee of the American Library Association, he promoted exchanges of library personnel and was instrumental in bringing many foreign librarians to this country and in providing library experience abroad for selected American librarians.

arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged into eight series: $$$$LIST00000

scopecontent.p: The Bishop papers consist of personal and professional files documenting William Warner Bishop's activities apart from his work as librarian at the University of Michigan. The librarian's files were separately received and continue to be maintained as part of the records of the University of Michigan Library.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series includes files letters, personal and professional, received and sent, in the period of 1891-1952. This series also includes letterbooks of copies of outgoing letters written while Bishop was at the Library of Congress as the Superintendent of the Reading Room. The dates of the letterbooks are 1907 to 1915.

odd.p: (copies of outgoing correspondence of WWB as superintendent of the reading room of the Library of Congress)

scopecontent.p: The Articles, Lectures, and Addresses series consists of writings and speeches primarily in the period following Bishop's coming to the University of Michigan. The files in this series are dated 1919-1951.

American Library Association is a series consisting of general correspondence, committee files, and other subject files detailing Bishop's lifelong association with the ALA. This series includes extensive documentation of his work with the Committee on International Relations and the Committee on Resources.

scopecontent.p: The series - Carnegie Corporation of New York - pertains to Bishop's professional relationship with this foundation and his participation on various of its advisory groups.

scopecontent.p: Topical Files, arranged alphabetically, consist of correspondence and other papers relating to Bishop's other organizational and personal interests.

did.unittitle: American Book Center for Devastated Libraries
Joint Committee on Books for Devastated Libraries
Library of Congress: Catalog of Printed Cards
Our Lady of the Lake College

scopecontent.p: The Biographical/personal and miscellaneous series consists of biographical information, files relating to the reunions and other alumni activities of the class of 1892 and 1893 of the University of Michigan, and Christmas cards from the period of 1929-1930 There are also three personal diaries dated 1912, 1913, and 1916.

odd.p: (see also diplomas in oversize folder Ac)

did.unittitle: U-M Class of 1892 alumni and reunion material
U-M Class of 1893 alumni and reunion materials

scopecontent.p: Student Notebooks date from 1890 to 1893 when Bishop was a student at the University of Michigan. This series is of most importance for the notes taken by Bishop on the philosophy lectures of John Dewey. Microfilm copies of these notes are available for inter-library loan.

did.unittitle: Notes and lectures on classical studies

odd.p: (include notes on the philosophy lectures of John Dewey; microfilm copy of Dewey lectures also available)

scopecontent.p: The Photographs include portraits, photographs of Bishop receiving awards or participating in various library functions and conventions. (The photographs series also includes oversize photos in Ac folder.)
